articles.headline: At the Vatican, a Shift in Tone Toward Gays and Divorce
articles.snippet: In remarkably conciliatory language, a synod of bishops appeared to reflect the more tolerant and inclusive direction Pope Francis has set for the church.
articles.abstract: In remarkably conciliatory language, a synod of bishops appeared to reflect the more tolerant and inclusive direction Pope Francis has set for the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In a marked shift in tone likely to be discussed in parishes around the world, an assembly of Roman Catholic bishops convened by Pope Francis at the Vatican released a preliminary document on Monday calling for the church to welcome and accept gay people, unmarried couples and those who have divorced, as well as the children of these less traditional families.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: A Symbolic Vote in Britain Recognizes a Palestinian State
articles.snippet: The action by Parliament was seen as an indication of how public opinion has shifted since the breakdown of peace talks and the Gaza conflict.
articles.abstract: The action by Parliament was seen as an indication of how public opinion has shifted since the breakdown of peace talks and the Gaza conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Against a backdrop of growing impatience across Europe with Israeli policy, Britain’s Parliament overwhelmingly passed a nonbinding resolution Monday night to give diplomatic recognition to a Palestinian state. The vote was a symbolic but potent indication of how public opinion has shifted since the breakdown of American-sponsored peace negotiations and the conflict in Gaza this summer.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: OPEC Split as Oil Prices Fall Sharply
articles.snippet: The drop comes as demand for petroleum is declining worldwide and the market is flooded with oil, including increased production in the United States.
articles.abstract: The drop comes as demand for petroleum is declining worldwide and the market is flooded with oil, including increased production in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices sank again on Monday, giving consumers more of a break and causing a split among OPEC leaders about what action should be taken, if any, to halt the slide.

articles.headline: Household Finances May Curb Holiday Spending
articles.snippet: Competition for shoppers’ dollars include health care and child care, personal savings, and even the new iPhone 6.
articles.abstract: Competition for shoppers’ dollars include health care and child care, personal savings, and even the new iPhone 6.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s going to be a frenetic holiday sales season. Kmart has already begun its Christmas advertising blitz, and surveys show a resurgence of interest in Black Friday bargains.

articles.headline: Calculating the Grim Economic Costs of Ebola Outbreak
articles.snippet: The topic everyone on Wall Street is discussing urgently but quietly isn’t the volatile stock market. It is Ebola.
articles.abstract: The topic everyone on Wall Street is discussing urgently but quietly isn’t the volatile stock market. It is Ebola.
articles.lead_paragraph: The topic everyone on Wall Street is discussing urgently but quietly isn’t the volatile stock market.

articles.headline: Putting the Berkshire Hathaway Brand Before Warren Buffett
articles.snippet: While Mr. Buffett is well known for his financial success, his holding company has little following outside Wall Street — but an effort is underway to change that.
articles.abstract: While Mr. Buffett is well known for his financial success, his holding company has little following outside Wall Street — but an effort is underway to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Surrounded by three beaming cheerleaders, Warren Buffett wears a white Oxford shirt emblazoned with the logo of his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway. A $100 bill appears to peek out of his front pocket, but it’s actually a replica embroidered onto the fabric.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and David Gelles

articles.headline: Questions Rise on Preparations at Hospitals to Deal With Ebola
articles.snippet: After a nurse at a Dallas hospital contracted Ebola, medical experts have begun to suggest that it might be better to transfer patients to designated centers with special expertise.
articles.abstract: After a nurse at a Dallas hospital contracted Ebola, medical experts have begun to suggest that it might be better to transfer patients to designated centers with special expertise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials have offered repeated assurances that most American hospitals can safely treat Ebola, but Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, which had years of preparation for just such a crisis, found out how hard that is while it cared for three Ebola patients.

articles.headline: Senate Contest in South Dakota Is Free-for-All
articles.snippet: A race that most had thought was safely Republican is suddenly the focus of national attention, thanks to the surprisingly successful candidacy of an independent.
articles.abstract: A race that most had thought was safely Republican is suddenly the focus of national attention, thanks to the surprisingly successful candidacy of an independent.
articles.lead_paragraph: VERMILLION, S.D. — One candidate will recite cowboy poetry on Wednesday at a Sioux Falls restaurant. A second thundered against his party as know-nothings who didn’t understand his state. A third until recently had been spurned by his would-be allies and donors, and a fourth runs African safaris in his spare time while railing against the size of the federal government.

articles.headline: Another Scandal Hits Citigroup’s Moneymaking Mexican Division
articles.snippet: The sprawling global bank also said it was scaling back its consumer business across Europe, Latin America and Asia.
articles.abstract: The sprawling global bank also said it was scaling back its consumer business across Europe, Latin America and Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:41 p.m. | The accusations read like a pulp thriller: Citigroup employees in Mexico are suspected of pocketing millions of dollars in kickbacks from vendors. And bodyguards for bank executives bought audio recordings of personal phone calls and created shell companies to disguise their fraud.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Converse Sues to Protect Its Chuck Taylor All Stars
articles.snippet: The footwear maker is filing trademark infringement lawsuits against 31 retailers, including Walmart, Kmart and Skechers, to protect core design elements.
articles.abstract: The footwear maker is filing trademark infringement lawsuits against 31 retailers, including Walmart, Kmart and Skechers, to protect core design elements.
articles.lead_paragraph: First came the athletes, then the greasers. Then came the nonconformists, the teenagers and finally the baby boomers. The shoe manufacturer Converse has sold its brand of cool and whiff of rebellion to generations of Americans.

articles.headline: Ireland to Phase Out ‘Double Irish’ Tax Break Used by Tech Giants
articles.snippet: The provision known as the “double Irish,” used by companies like Google to reduce their bills, has been under scrutiny from European Union regulators.
articles.abstract: The provision known as the “double Irish,” used by companies like Google to reduce their bills, has been under scrutiny from European Union regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ireland’s government on Tuesday responded to the clamorous criticism of its business-friendly tax arrangements by closing a loophole used by multinational giants like Google.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Mark Scott
